…amen to that

content.body: Curious that Element chooses the fingerprint image as the link card image
We should likely just add some proper OpenGraph metadata... kitchen sink probably?
Isn't OpenGraph very much non-standard?
`<meta property>` doesn't exist. Probably something we'd have to admit defeat on, but that would be quite a bit of work.
content.formatted_body: <meta property> doesn't exist. Probably something we'd have to admit defeat on, but that would be quite a bit of work.

content.body: annevk: I just realized that something with unknownMarkup that I had forgotten about. Unlike for elements, we don't know which attributes are known or unknown.
content.formatted_body: annevk: I just realized that something with unknownMarkup that I had forgotten about. Unlike for elements, we don't know which attributes are known or unknown.

content.body: evilpie: that seems like something we can maintain; I also think that we should not have a global list for attributes that are essentially local to elements, we should flatten that (except for actual global attributes)
content.formatted_body: evilpie: that seems like something we can maintain; I also think that we should not have a global list for attributes that are essentially local to elements, we should flatten that (except for actual global attributes)

content.body: I am not sure what you mean with flatten in that context. Do you mean have a list of attributes per element or not? { element-tag -> [attributes] }
We talked about this a few times before, but at least for Gecko creating such a list is not straightforward
evilpie: yeah, similar to how `elements` works, embrace that in the default policy
content.formatted_body: evilpie: yeah, similar to how elements works, embrace that in the default policy

content.body: Just to clarify this, we would basically needs to maps { elements -> supported-attributes } and { elements -> baseline-allowed-attributes }, because otherwise we can't decide if "onclick" is a known not-allowed attribute, or an unknown attribute.

* Just to clarify this, we would basically needs two maps { elements -> supported-attributes } and { elements -> baseline-allowed-attributes }, because otherwise we can't decide if "onclick" is a known not-allowed attribute, or an unknown attribute.

m.new_content.body: Just to clarify this, we would basically needs two maps { elements -> supported-attributes } and { elements -> baseline-allowed-attributes }, because otherwise we can't decide if "onclick" is a known not-allowed attribute, or an unknown attribute.

content.body: we don't need this for elements, because we currently do this weird thing with basically checking for instanceof HTMLUnknownElement
Which is a bit of a hack...
And doesn't work for MathML or SVG I'd think.
yes, I think we have for that https://github.com/WICG/sanitizer-api/issues/147
maintaining a list of supported elements is a lot easier still
evilpie: I think. that's why it's really important this becomes part of HTML, so that whenever we add an element or attribute, all the relevant lists get updated
content.formatted_body: evilpie: I think. that's why it's really important this becomes part of HTML, so that whenever we add an element or attribute, all the relevant lists get updated

content.body: HTMLUnknownElement check also doesn't work for custom elements
